title: Core blimey! River is transformed into an apple-bobber's Halloween dream
text:
A river was transformed into an apple-bobbers Halloween dream - after thousands were washed away in a flood.

Heavy rain and flooding left the river awash with fallen fruit from a cider orchard.

The flood of fruit happened after a heavy downfall hit the River Wye near Staunton-on-Wye, Herefordshire.

A huge crop of apples was washed into the Wye near Stanton after recent heavy rains

A picture of the floating fruit was shared on social media by lecturer Kelly Bridge.

Kelly, 43, said: 'A whole new spin on bobbing for apples.

'This is probably quite a large part of someone's harvest floating down the river in Staunton on Wye Herefordshire.'

While it provides a perfect place for apple-bobbers to play the traditional Halloween game, cider fans will be mourning the loss.

Apple bobbing is a traditional game at this time of year but the Wye may present a challenge

One comment said: 'Cider drinkers will be pulling their hair out, tonnes of fruit washed down the Wye.'

Parts of the Wye Valley saw the highest levels of flooding on record this week with several flood warnings remaining in place.
description: Thousands of apples were pictured completely covered the surface of the River Wye near Staunton in Herefordshire. It is believed they were washed from a nearby cider orchard in heavy rains.
